{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}} [[File:Air Force One photo op incident- altered by DoD.jpg|thumb|400px|This picture of the plane during the photo op was released by the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]]. See also [[:File:Air Force One photo op incident.jpg|the original unaltered photo]].]] [[File:Air Force One over Mt. Rushmore.jpg|thumb|The Mount Rushmore Air Force One image]] The '''''Air Force One'' photo op incident''' occurred on the morning of April 27, 2009, when a [[Boeing VC-25]] (a [[Boeing 747]] military variant used as ''[[Air Force One]]'' when the president is aboard), followed by a [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]] [[F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16]] jet fighter, flew low and circled the [[Upper New York Bay]], site of the [[Statue of Liberty National Monument]]. President [[Barack Obama]] was not on board the aircraft during the incident. Although the planes were engaged in a [[photo op]] and [[military exercise|training exercise]], the citizens of [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[New Jersey]] had not been informed in advance, and some thought it could be the makings of a [[terrorist attack]] similar to the [[September 11 attacks]]. Some people ran out of buildings and panicked in the streets. Some buildings ordered evacuations.<ref>{{cite news |first1= Suzanne |last1= Sataline |first2= Jonathan D. |last2= Rockoff |first3= Christopher |last3= Conkey |lastauthoramp= yes |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124084127590859371 |title= A 'Classified' Photo Op Turns Into a Soaring Blunder for the White House |work= [[The Wall Street Journal]] |date= April 28, 2009}}</ref>
==Incident== The [[flypast|flyby]] was approved by [[Louis Caldera]], director of the [[White House Military Office]], to update the previous image of the aircraft flying over [[Mount Rushmore]]. [[Fran Townsend]], [[Homeland Security Council|Homeland Security Advisor]] to [[George W. Bush]], said the flyby was "crass insensitivity." She also said, "I'd call this felony stupidity. This is probably not the right job for Mr. Caldera to be in if he didn't understand the likely reaction of New Yorkers, of the mayor."<ref name="cnn.com" /> The [[Mayor of New York City]], [[Michael Bloomberg]], said that the flyby "defies the imagination." Senator [[Charles Schumer]] (D-New York) said the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] not telling the public about the flyby in advance "borders on being either cruel or very, very stupid." President [[Barack Obama]] did not know about the flyby until after it happened, and he stated, "It was a mistake. It was something we found out about along with all of you. And it will not happen again." Although the city's police department had been notified in advance, they had been instructed not to tell the public.<ref name="cnn.com">{{cite news |first1= Mythili |last1= Rao |first2= Ed |last2= Henry |lastauthoramp= yes |url= http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/04/28/low.flying.plane/index.html |title= 'Furious' Obama Orders Review of NY Plane Flyover |date= April 28, 2009 |publisher= CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Michael |last=Muskal |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-obama-plane29-2009apr29,0,2498563.story |title=Obama Calls Plane's Manhattan Photo-Op 'a Mistake' |date=April 28, 2009 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=April 28, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430143711/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-obama-plane29-2009apr29%2C0%2C2498563.story |archivedate=April 30, 2009 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
Caldera said of his actions, "Last week, I approved a mission over New York. I take responsibility for that decision... While federal authorities took the proper steps to notify state and local authorities in New York and New Jersey, it's clear that the mission created confusion and disruption. I apologize and take responsibility for any distress that flight caused."<ref>{{cite news |first= Michael |last= Winter |url= http://blogs.usatoday.com/ondeadline/2009/04/white-house-sorry-for-ny-flyover.html |title= White House Sorry for NYC Flyover |department= On Deadline |work= [[USA Today]] |date= April 27, 2009 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090501065147/http://blogs.usatoday.com/ondeadline/2009/04/white-house-sorry-for-ny-flyover.html |archivedate= May 1, 2009}}</ref>
[[CBS News]]'s New York City affiliate [[WCBS-TV]] obtained a memo from the [[Federal Aviation Administration]]'s James Johnston saying that the agency was aware of "the possibility of public concern regarding DOD ([[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]]) aircraft flying at low altitudes" in and around the city.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.avweb.com/pdf/NewYorkCityFlyoverMemo.pdf |format= PDF |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120926115259/http://www.avweb.com/pdf/NewYorkCityFlyoverMemo.pdf |archivedate= September 26, 2012 |title= Flight Notification- New York City -Statue of Liberty Photo Op, Upper New York Bay / Newark Bay on April 27, 2009, 10:00L. (amended 4/23) |via=Avweb.com |first= James J. |last= Johnston |publisher= FAA Air Traffic}}</ref> However, the agency demanded total secrecy from the [[NYPD|city's police department]], the [[United States Secret Service|Secret Service]], the [[FBI]], and the mayor's office, and threatened federal sanctions if the secret was revealed.<ref>{{cite news |first= Marcia |last= Kramer |url= http://wcbstv.com/topstories/air.force.one.2.996457.html |title= FAA Memo: Feds Knew Flyover Would Cause NYC Panic |location= New York |publisher= [[WCBS-TV]] |date= April 29, 2009 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100318054350/http://wcbstv.com/topstories/air.force.one.2.996457.html |archivedate= March 18, 2010}}</ref>
Air Force officials estimated the cost for the photo shoot mission to be around $328,835, but stated that "the hours would have been flown regardless, and the expenses would have been accrued on a different mission".<ref name="cnn.com"/>
The day after the flyby, White House spokesperson [[Robert Gibbs]] said that the incident would be investigated by Deputy Chief of Staff [[Jim Messina (politician)|Jim Messina]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/04/28/Review-of-New-York-City-flyover-ordered/UPI-94661240962630/ |title= Review of New York City Flyover Ordered |publisher= [[United Press International]] |date= April 28, 2009}}</ref> Gibbs also said that President Obama was "furious" about the flyby. However, Gibbs did not answer reporters' repeated questions about whether or not Caldera would lose his job. [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] press secretary [[Geoff S. Morrell|Geoff Morrell]] said that the idea for the flyby originated in the White House Military Office.<ref>{{cite news |first1= Michael D. |last1= Shear |first2= Ann Scott |last2= Tyson |lastauthoramp= yes |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/28/AR2009042800346.html?hpid=sec-nation |title= Official Who Approved Air Force One Flyover May Be Fired |work= The Washington Post |date= April 29, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.defenselink.mil/transcripts/transcript.aspx?transcriptid=4409 |title= DoD News Briefing with Geoff Morrell from the Pentagon |first= Geoff |last= Morrell |date= April 28, 2009 |type= Transcript |publisher= United States Department of Defense}}</ref> Gibbs also stated, "Because this was a training mission, the only people on that plane were Air Force personnel."<ref>{{cite web |first= Robert |last= Gibbs |url= http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Briefing-by-White-House-Press-Secretary-Robert-Gibbs-4-28-09 |title= Press Briefing By Press Secretary Robert Gibbs |publisher= The White House, Office of the Press Secretary |date= April 28, 2009 |access-date= May 4, 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090504082245/http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Briefing-by-White-House-Press-Secretary-Robert-Gibbs-4-28-09/ |archive-date= May 4, 2009 |dead-url= yes |df= mdy-all }}</ref>
On May 4, 2009, the White House told reporters that the publicity photos taken during the flight would not be shown to the public.<ref>{{cite news |author= Post Staff |url= http://www.nypost.com/seven/05052009/news/regionalnews/phantom_air_farce_pictures_167671.htm |title= Phantom Air Farce Pictures |work= [[New York Post]] |date= May 5, 2009}}</ref> Two days later, the White House reversed course and told reporters that the publicity photos taken during the flight could be released soon.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/05/06/air.force.one.flyover/index.html |title= White House Plans to Release Plane Flyover Report, Photo |publisher= [[CNN]] |date= May 6, 2009}}</ref> On May 8, 2009, the photo was released and it was reported that Caldera had resigned.<ref>{{cite news |first= Ed |last= Hornick |url= http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/05/08/air.force.one.flyover/ |title= Official who OK'd Air Force One Jet Flyover Resigns |publisher= CNN |date= May 8, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ny1.com/Default.aspx?ArID=98785 |title=Air Force One Photo Released. Was It Worth It? |publisher=[[NY1]] |date=May 8, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In his letter of resignation,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.findlaw.com/ap_stories/a/w/1151/05-08-2009/20090508142009_54.html |title=Text of Caldera's Resignation Letter to Obama |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[FindLaw]] |date=May 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511172220/http://news.findlaw.com/ap_stories/a/w/1151/05-08-2009/20090508142009_54.html |archivedate=May 11, 2009 }}</ref> Caldera told the president that after the incident he was no longer able to "effectively lead the White House Military Office" due to the furor over the incident.<ref>{{cite news |first= Jeff |last= Zeleny |date= May 8, 2009 |url= http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/08/after-air-force-one-flyover-military-office-director-resigns/?hp |title= After Flyover of Air Force One Backup, Military Office Director Resigns |department= The Caucus |work= [[The New York Times]] }}</ref> On July 31, 2009, 146 photos and related documents were released through the Department of Defense's [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] procedures.{{Citation Needed|date=June 2017}}
In August, the [[Associated Press]] reported that the Air Force used the social networking site [[Twitter]] to track the negative public reaction to the incident.<ref>{{cite news |first= Richard |last= Lardner |url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jxWrQTG834rUTvAFOYXCGLNJ-zWQD99VSGNO0 |title= Air Force Used Twitter to Track NY Flyover Fallout |agency= Associated Press |work= Google News |date= August 10, 2009 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090813100648/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jxWrQTG834rUTvAFOYXCGLNJ-zWQD99VSGNO0 |archivedate= August 13, 2009}}</ref> Caldera's replacement, George Mulligan, was announced on October 16, 2009.<ref>{{cite news |last= McMichael |first= William H. |url= http://militarytimes.com/news/2009/10/military_747_flyover_caldera_102009w/ |title= Replacement Named after 747 Flyover Fiasco |work= [[Military Times]] |date= October 20, 2009}}</ref>

Includes 146 photos, flight manifest, and supporting Air Force documents.

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} [[File:Paul Berg in 1980.jpg|thumb|right|[[Paul Berg]], a leading researcher in the field of [[recombinant DNA technology]], who subsequently shared the 1980 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]] with [[Walter Gilbert]] and [[Frederick Sanger]], helped organize the conference.]] The '''Asilomar Conference on Recombinant DNA''' was an influential [[academic conference|conference]] organized by [[Paul Berg]]<ref>“First recombinant DNA.” The Human Genome Project. http://www.genome.gov/25520302 accessed 12 November 2006</ref> to discuss the potential [[biohazard]]s and regulation of [[biotechnology]], held in February 1975 at a conference center at [[Asilomar State Beach]].<ref name="asilomar">[[Paul Berg]], [[David Baltimore]], [[Sydney Brenner]], [[Richard O. Roblin III]], and [[Maxine F. Singer]]. “Summary Statement of the Asilomar Conference on Recombinant DNA Molecules”. ''Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci.'' Vol. 72, No. 6, pp. 1981-1984, (June 1975): 1981.</ref> A group of about 140 professionals (primarily [[biologist]]s, but also including [[lawyer]]s and [[physician]]s) participated in the conference to draw up voluntary guidelines to ensure the safety of [[recombinant DNA]] technology. The conference also placed scientific research more into the public domain, and can be seen as applying a version of the [[precautionary principle]].
The effects of these guidelines are still being felt through the biotechnology industry and the participation of the general public in scientific discourse.<ref name="recombinant">Paul Berg and Maxine F. Singer. “The recombinant DNA controversy: Twenty years later”. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. Vol 92, pp. 9011-9013, (Sept. 1995): 9011.</ref> Due to potential safety hazards, scientists worldwide had halted experiments using recombinant DNA technology, which entailed combining DNAs from different organisms.<ref name="asilomar" /><ref name ="recombinant" /> After the establishment of the guidelines during the conference, scientists continued with their research, which increased fundamental knowledge about biology and the public's interest in [[biomedical research]].<ref>Berg and Singer (1995), pp. 9011-12</ref>
==Background: recombinant DNA technology== [[Recombinant DNA]] technology arose as a result of advances in biology that began in the 1950s and 60’s. During these decades, a tradition of merging the structural, biochemical and informational approaches to the central problems of classical genetics became more apparent. Two main underlying concepts of this tradition were that genes consisted of DNA and that DNA encoded information that determined the processes of replication and protein synthesis. These concepts were embodied in the model of DNA produced through the combined efforts of [[James D. Watson|James Watson]], [[Francis Crick]],and [[Rosalind Franklin]]. Further research on the Watson-Crick model yielded theoretical advances that were reflected in new capacities to manipulate DNA.<ref>Susan Wright. "Recombinant DNA Technology and Its Social Transformation, 1972-1982." ''[[Osiris (journal)|Osiris]]'', 2nd Series, Vol. 2 (1986): 305</ref> One of these capacities was recombinant DNA technology.
===Experimental design=== This technology entails the joining of DNA from different species and the subsequent insertion of the hybrid DNA into a host cell. One of the first individuals to develop recombinant DNA technology was a biochemist at Stanford by the name of Paul Berg.<ref>Paul Berg and Maxine F. Singer. “The recombinant DNA controversy: Twenty years later”. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. Vol 92, pp. 9011-9013, (Sept. 1995)</ref> In his experimental design in 1974, he cleaved (cut into fragments) the monkey virus SV40. He then cleaved the double helix of another virus; an antibacterial agent known as [[Lambda phage|bacteriophage lambda]]. In the third step, he fastened DNA from the SV40 to DNA from the bacteriophage lambda. The final step involved placing the mutant genetic material into a laboratory strain of the E. coli bacterium. This last step, however, was not completed in the original experiment.<ref name="Carmen, Ira H. 1985 pp. 61-62">Carmen, Ira H. ''Cloning and the Constitution: An Inquiry into Governmental Policymaking and Genetic Experimentation''. (Madison: University of Wisconsin Press, 1985) pp. 61-62.</ref>
===Initial bio-safety concerns=== Berg did not complete his final step due to the pleas of several fellow investigators who feared the biohazards associated with the last step. The SV40 was known to cause cancer tumors to develop in mice. Additionally, the E. coli bacterium (although not the strain used by Berg) inhabited the human intestinal tract. For these reasons, the other investigators feared that the final step would create cloned SV40 DNA that might escape into the environment and infect laboratory workers. These workers could then become cancer victims.<ref name="Carmen, Ira H. 1985 pp. 61-62"/>
Concern about this potential biohazard, along with others, caused a group of leading researchers to send a letter to the president of the National Academy of Science (NAS). In this letter, they requested that he appoint an ad hoc committee to study the bio-safety ramifications of this new technology. This committee, called the Committee on Recombinant DNA molecules of the National Academy of Science, U.S.A., held in 1974, concluded that an international conference was necessary to resolve the issue and that until that time, scientists should halt experiments involving recombinant DNA technology.<ref>Carmen, Ira H. ''Cloning and the Constitution: An Inquiry into Governmental Policymaking and Genetic Experimentation''. (Madison: University of Wisconsin Press, 1985)</ref>
==Asilomar Conference==
===Established principles=== The Asilomar Conference on Recombinant DNA took place at the [[Asilomar Conference Grounds|Asilomar Conference Center]] on California's Monterey Peninsula in 1975. The main goal of the conference was to address the biohazards presented by recombinant DNA technology. During the conference, the principles guiding the recommendations for how to conduct experiments using this technology safely were established. The first principle for dealing with potential risks was that containment should be made an essential consideration in the experimental design. A second principle was that the effectiveness of the containment should match the estimated risk as closely as possible.<ref>[[Paul Berg]], [[David Baltimore]], [[Sydney Brenner]], [[Richard O. Roblin III]], and [[Maxine F. Singer]]. “Summary Statement of the Asilomar Conference on Recombinant DNA Molecules”. ''Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci.'' Vol. 72, No. 6, pp. 1981-1984, (June 1975)</ref>
The conference also suggested the use of biological barriers to limit the spread of recombinant DNA. Such biological barriers included fastidious bacterial hosts that were unable to survive in natural environments. Other barriers were nontransmissible and equally fastidious vectors (plasmids, bacteriophages, or other viruses) that were able to grow in only specified hosts.<ref name="Berg et al. 1975, p. 1982">Berg et al. (1975), p. 1982</ref>
In addition to biological barriers, the conference advocated the use of additional safety factors. One such safety factor was physical containment, exemplified by the use of hoods or where applicable, limited access or negative pressure laboratories. Another factor was the strict adherence to good microbiological practices, which would limit the escape of organisms from the experimental situation. Additionally, the education and training of all personnel involved in the experiments would be essential to effective containment measures.<ref name="Berg et al. 1975, p. 1982"/>
===Recommendations given=== The Asilomar Conference also gave recommendations for matching the types of containment necessary for different types of experiments. These recommendations were based on the different levels of risk associated with the experiment, which would require different levels of containment. These levels were minimal, low, moderate and high risk. The minimal risk level of containment was intended for experiments in which the biohazards could be accurately assessed and were expected to be minimal. Low risk containment was appropriate for experiments that generated novel biotypes but where the available information indicated that the recombinant DNA could not either alter appreciably the ecological behavior of the recipient species, increase significantly its pathogenicity or prevent effective treatments of any resulting infections. The moderate risk level of containment was intended for experiments in which there was a probability of generating an agent with a significant potential for pathogenicity or ecological disruption. High-risk containment was intended for experiments in which the potential for ecological disruption or pathogenicity of the modified organism could be severe and thereby pose a serious biohazard to laboratory personnel or to the public. These levels of containments, along with the previously mentioned safety measures, formed the basis for the guidelines used by investigators in future experiments that involved the construction and propagation of recombinant DNA molecules using DNA from prokaryotes, bacteriophages and other plasmids, animal viruses and eukaryotes.<ref name="Berg et al. 1975, p. 1982"/>
===Recommendations applied to experiments=== For prokaryotes, bacteriophages and other plasmids, experiments could be performed in minimal risk containment facilities when the construction of recombinant DNA molecules and their propagation involved prokaryotic agents that were known to exchange genetic information naturally.<ref>Berg et al. (1975), pp. 1982-83</ref> For experiments involving the creation and propagation of recombinant DNA molecules from DNAs of species that ordinarily did not exchange genetic information and generate novel biotypes, the experiments were to be performed in at least in a low risk containment facility. If the experiment increased the pathogenicity of the recipient species or result in new metabolic pathways in species, then moderate or high-risk containment facilities were to be used. In experiments where the range of resistance of established human pathogens to therapeutically useful antibiotics or disinfectants was extended, the experiments were to be undertaken only in moderate or high-risk containment facilities.<ref name="Berg et al. 1975, p. 1983">Berg et al. (1975), p. 1983</ref>
When working with animal viruses, experiments that involved the linkage of viral genomes or genome segments to prokaryotic vectors and their propagation in prokaryotic cells were to be conducted only with vector-host systems that had demonstrated restricted growth capabilities outside the laboratory and in moderate risk containment facilities. As safer vector-host systems became available, such experiments could be performed in low risk facilities. In experiments designed to introduce or propagate DNA from non-viral or other low risk agents in animal cells, only low risk animal DNA could be used as vectors and the manipulations were to be confined to moderate risk containment facilities.<ref name="Berg et al. 1975, p. 1983"/>
With eukaryotes, attempts to clone segments of DNA using recombinant DNA technology from warm-blooded vertebrates genomes were to be performed only with vector-host systems that had demonstrably restricted growth capabilities outside the laboratory and in a moderate risk containment facility. This was because they potentially contained cryptic viral genomes that were potentially pathogenic to humans. However, unless the organism made a dangerous product, recombinant DNAs from cold-blooded vertebrates and all other lower eukaryotes could be constructed and propagated with the safest vector-host system available in low risk containment facilities. Additionally, purified DNA from any source that performed known functions and was judged to be non-toxic could be cloned with available vectors in low risk containment facilities.<ref name="Berg et al. 1975, p. 1983"/>
===Prohibited experiments=== In addition to regulating the experiments that were conducted, the guidelines also forbade the performance of other experiments. One such experiment was the cloning of recombinant DNAs derived from highly pathogenic organisms. In addition, neither the cloning of DNA containing toxin genes, nor large scale experiments using recombinant DNAs that were able to make products that were potentially harmful to humans, animals or plants were allowed under the guidelines. These experiments were banned because the potential biohazards could not be contained by the then current safety precautions.<ref name="Berg et al. 1975, p. 1983"/>
===Science and the general public=== The participants of the Asilomar Conference also endeavored to bring science into the domain of the general public, with a possible motivation being the [[Watergate scandal]]. The scandal resulted from a bungled break-in at the Watergate hotel, which served as the Democratic National Committee headquarters in 1972. Two years after the burglary, taped evidence was discovered that indicated that President Nixon had discussed a cover-up a week after it. Three days following the release of the tape, Nixon resigned from his presidential office. This event focused the nation's attention on the problem of government secrecy fostering illegal and immoral behavior and it has been suggested by the political scientist, Ira H. Carmen, that this motivated the scientists at the Asilomar Conference to bring science into the public eye to ensure that they would not be accused of a cover-up.<ref>Fred Smoller. “Watergate Revisited.” ''PS: Political Science and Politics'', Vol. 25, No. 2 (June 1992): 225; and Carmen, ''Cloning and the Constitution'', p. 63</ref> Additionally, according to Dr. Berg and Dr. Singer, by being forthright, scientists avoided restrictive legislation due to the development of a consensus on how they were to conduct their research.<ref name="Berg and Singer 1995, p. 9012">Berg and Singer (1995), p. 9012</ref>
Bringing science into the public eye also coincided with the rapid rate at which recombinant DNA technology entered the industrial world. Because of the practical applications of the technology, funding for research using it started coming more from the private sector and less from the public sector. In addition, many molecular biologists who once confined themselves to academia, developed ties with private industry as equity owners, corporate executives and consultants.<ref>Wright, "Recombinant DNA Technology and Its Social Transformation", p. 303</ref> This led to the creation of a biotechnology industry, although during this time, public debates occur over the hazards of recombinant DNA.<ref name="Wright p. 360">Wright, "Recombinant DNA Technology and Its Social Transformation", p. 360</ref> These debates were eventually won over by scientists who stated that the hazards were exaggerated and that the research could be conducted safely.<ref>Susan Wright. “Molecular Biology or Molecular Politics? The Production of Scientific Consensus on the Hazards of Recombinant DNA Technology.” ''Social Studies of Science'', Vol. 16, No. 4 (Nov. 1986). pp. 595-96.</ref> Such was seen in the Ascot report, found in the Federal Register in March 1978. This report emphasized that the hazards of recombinant DNA to the general community were small to the point that they were of no practical consequence to the general public.<ref>Wright, “Molecular Biology or Molecular Politics?”, p. 612.</ref> For this reason, along with high economic pressures for industrial development and a more supportive political environment that existed after 1979, research and industry based on recombinant DNA continued to expand.<ref name="Wright p. 360"/>
==Significance of the conference== Years after the conference, people ascribed a large amount of significance to it. According to Paul Berg and [[Maxine Singer]] in 1995, the conference marked the beginning of an exceptional era for both science and the public discussion of science policy. The guidelines devised by the conference enabled scientists to conduct experiments with recombinant DNA technology, which by 1995 dominated biological research. This research, in turn, increased knowledge about fundamental life processes, such as the cell cycle. Additionally, the conference along with public debates on recombinant DNA, increased public interest in biomedical research and molecular genetics. For this reason, by 1995, genetics and its vocabulary had become a part of the daily press and television news. This, in turn, stimulated knowledgeable public discussion about some of the social, political and environmental issues that emerged from genetic medicine and the use of genetically modified plants in agriculture. Another significant outcome of the conference was the precedent it set about how to respond to changes in scientific knowledge. According to the conference, the proper response to new scientific knowledge was to develop guidelines that governed how to regulate it.<ref name="Berg and Singer 1995, p. 9012"/>

[[Vista Organization]] | distributor = [[CBS]] | budget = | network = CBS | first_aired = January 4 | last_aired = 6, 1987 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''At Mother's Request''''' is a 1987 two-part television miniseries based on a true story (the [[Franklin Bradshaw murder]]). The movie stars [[E. G. Marshall]] and [[Stefanie Powers]]. ==Plot summary== Frances Schreuder, a mother who is very mean to her sons, especially when they don't measure up to her expectations, and very greedy, decides she wants her inheritance from her rich father, multimillionaire Franklin Bradshaw. Frances has done some evil things to get what she wants. For example, she has forged some of her father's checks to get things she wants and had her sons steal from him when they were visiting him in his [[Salt Lake City]] business from their [[New York City]] home the summer before his death. She decides she wants her money really soon and manipulates her son Marc into murdering her father. ==Cast== * [[E. G. Marshall]] as Frank Bradshaw * [[Stefanie Powers]] as Frances Schreuder * [[Doug McKeon]] as Marc Schreuder * [[Jenna von Oÿ]] as Audrey Schreuder * [[Corey Parker (actor)|Corey Parker]] as Larry Schreuder * [[Frances Lee McCain]] as Lois Turner * [[Terry O'Quinn]] as Jeol Campbell * [[Ray Baker (actor)|Ray Baker]] as Michael George * [[Frances Sternhagen]] as Berenice Bradshaw * [[Martin Donovan]] as Detective Rogen * [[George Sullivan (actor)|George Sullivan]] as Detective Voyles * [[Roberts Blossom]] as Doug Steele * [[Chris Noth]] as Steve Klein * [[Dan Lauria]] as Myles Manning * [[Louis Borgenicht]] as Stanley Turner * [[Nancy Borgenicht]] as Nancy Jones * [[Jasmine Guy]] as Bank Teller ==Production== Parts of the miniseries were shot in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]].{{cite book|last1=D'Arc|first1=James V.|title=When Hollywood came to town: a history of moviemaking in Utah|date=2010|publisher=Gibbs Smith|location=Layton, Utah|isbn=9781423605874|edition=1st}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0092590|title=At Mother's Request}} [[Category:1987 television films]] [[Category:1980s American television miniseries]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American television films]] {{US-tv-film-stub}}

'''Bach at the Sem''' is an annual sacred music concert series held on the campus of [[Concordia Seminary]] in suburban [[St. Louis]]. Bach at the Sem is an integral part of Concordia Seminary's educational and cultural programming to those who attend the seminary and to the St. Louis metropolitan community. It is the purpose and function of Bach at the Sem to profess the Christian faith through the proclamation of the Church's rich heritage of sacred and classical music, especially music of Lutheran composers. Bach at the Sem concentrates on music of [[Johann Sebastian Bach]] and is also dedicated to the performance of church music from the [[Renaissance]], [[Baroque]], [[classical music|Classical]], and [[Neoclassicism (music)|Neoclassical]] periods. Typically, five or six concert performances have been offered each concert season coincident with the academic year of the seminary. The venue is the Chapel of St. Titus and St. Timothy on the campus of Concordia Seminary; the audience is the seminary family of faculty, staff and students and metropolitan St. Louis.
The main performing ensemble for Bach at the Sem is the [[American Kantorei]]. The American Kantorei is an orchestral and choral ensemble founded in 1968 by its director, the Rev. Prof. [[Robert R. Bergt]]. Robert Bergt's untimely death in July 2011 resulted in the appointment of Dr. Jeral Becker, Director of Vocal and Choral Activities at St. Louis University, as Interim Muic Director of Bach at the Sem for the foreseeable future. Instrumentalists and Kantorei members include some of the finest trained musicians in the St. Louis area.

{{for|the hotel in Klamath Falls, Oregon|Baldwin Hotel}} {{Infobox building | name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_names = | alternate_names = | status = | image = Baldwin Hotel 1879.jpg | image_alt = Baldwin Hotel and Theatre | image_size = 250px | caption = Baldwin Hotel and Theatre | map_type = San Francisco County#California#USA | pushpin_label =Baldwin Hotel | map_alt = | map_caption = | relief = | altitude = | building_type = Masonry on steel | architectural_style = | structural_system = | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = [[Lucky Baldwin]] | current_tenants = | landlord = | location = | address = Market and Powell Streets, San Francisco | location_town = San Francisco | location_country = United States | coordinates = {{coord|37.7849|-122.4074|region:US-CA|display=inline}} | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = | completion_date = 1875–76 | opened_date = | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = | demolition_date = | destruction_date = 1898 | height = | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | roof = | top_floor = | observatory = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = | floor_area = | seating_type = | seating_capacity = | elevator_count = | architect = Sumner Bugbee,
[[Second Empire architecture|Second Empire style]] | architecture_firm = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | main_contractor = | awards = | designations = | ren_architect = | ren_firm = | ren_str_engineer = | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_awards = | rooms = | parking = | url = | embedded = | references = }} '''Baldwin Hotel''' was a 19th-century luxury hotel and theatre built by [[Comstock Lode]] millionaire, entrepreneur, and gambler [[Lucky Baldwin|Elias Jackson "Lucky" Baldwin]], formerly in downtown [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], [[California]]. It was located on [[Powell Street (San Francisco)|Powell Street]] at the corner of [[Market Street (San Francisco)|Market Street]], near the [[Union Square, San Francisco|Union Square]] area. ==History== [[File:Baldwin's Hotel and Theatre San Francisco.jpg|thumb|left|275px|Baldwin Hotel and Theatre,
on Powell Street at Market.]] The Baldwin Theatre was completed in 1875, and the Baldwin Hotel was completed around it in 1876. The hotel was designed in the [[Second Empire architecture|Second Empire style]] by architect Sumner Bugbee. The theatre featured touring performers and it was first known as Baldwin's Academy of Music. Most of the touring performers of the day appeared there.{{Cite journal|title = Baldwin Theatre - Oxford Reference|url = http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095442714}} The hotel and theatre occupied the entire block. The ground floor was divided into a number of large stores. A theatre attendee, [[Mrs. Frank Leslie]], described the building in 1877: ::{{quote|"In the evening, by way of severe contrast [to the Mission Dolores they visited earlier that day], we went to Baldwin's Theatre, attached to the hotel of the same name and just finished. It is really the prettiest to be seen in any part of the world -- a perfect little gem, fitted up like a bonbonniere in crimson satin and gold. The six proscenium boxes on either side, and the row of French boxes at the back are marvelously pretty. Nothing could be more rich and exquisite in refinement of taste. The symmetry of the house is unmarred by rows of pillars, the galleries being suspended from the roof." [http://nbc-lumber.com/Leslie/Ch20.htm California: a pleasure trip from Gotham to the Golden Gate] Mrs. Frank Leslie April, May, June, 1877}} ===Destruction=== The entire building was destroyed by fire in 1898.{{Cite web|title = Theatres, California Sheet Music (Duggan)|url = http://people.ischool.berkeley.edu/~mkduggan/theatres.html|website = people.ischool.berkeley.edu|access-date = 2016-02-20}}{{Cite web|title = The Sydney Mail - Google News Archive Search|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1302&dat=18981203&id=rVZVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=npUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2173,6932440|website = news.google.com|access-date = 2016-02-20}}{{Cite web|title = SAN FRANCISCO HOTEL FIRE; "Lucky" Baldwin's House Laid in Ruins by Flames. LOSS OF LIFE MAY BE GREAT Only Two Victims' Bodies So Far Recovered -- Theatre in the Building Also Burned.|url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1898/11/24/102496522.pdf|website = query.nytimes.com|access-date = 2016-02-20}}{{Cite web|title = Lewis Meyers {{!}} Skagway Stories|url = http://www.skagwaystories.org/2010/09/24/lewis-meyers|access-date = 2016-02-20}} Two people were killed, and the adjacent Columbia Theater building on Powell Street suffered considerable damage.{{Cite web|title = San Francisco, CA Baldwin Hotel Fire|url = http://www3.gendisasters.com/california/3418/san-francisco%252C-ca-baldwin-hotel-fire%252C-nov-1898|website = www3.gendisasters.com|access-date = 2016-02-20}} After the Baldwin Hotel building was demolished, the [[Flood Building]] was built on the site in 1904. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area}} ==External links== * [http://www3.gendisasters.com/california/6940/san-francisco-ca-hotel-block-destroyed-nov-1898 Gendisasters.com: Baldwin Hotel Block Destroyed, Nov 1898, San Francisco, CA] — ''narrative accounts''. {{Commons Category|Baldwin Hotel (San Francisco, 1878-1898)|position=left}} [[Category:Hotels in San Francisco]] [[Category:Theatres in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Market Street (San Francisco)]] [[Category:Union Square, San Francisco]] [[Category:Hotel buildings completed in 1876]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1875]] [[Category:Defunct hotels in California]] [[Category:Demolished hotels in the United States]] [[Category:Demolished theatres in California]] [[Category:Former buildings and structures in San Francisco]] [[Category:1875 establishments in California]] [[Category:Hotels established in 1876]] [[Category:1876 establishments in California]] [[Category:1898 disestablishments in California]] [[Category:19th century in San Francisco]] [[Category:Second Empire architecture in California]]

Seven cities submitted '''bids for 2016 Summer Olympics and Paralympics''' on September 13, 2007, aiming to host the ''Games of the XXXI Olympiad''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Seven Applicant NOCs/Cities for the 2016 Games|url=http://www.olympic.org/en/content/Media/?articleId=55036|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=September 14, 2007|publisher=International Olympic Committee}}</ref> All of them were recognized by the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) on September 14, 2007, becoming Applicant cities.<ref>{{cite web|title=7 Applicant NOCs/Cities for the 2016 Olympic Games|url=http://www.olympic.org/en/content/Media/?articleId=55035|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=September 14, 2007|publisher=International Olympic Committee}}</ref> Although several cities submitted to be in consideration to host the 2016 Olympics, including [[New York City]] and [[Los Angeles]], on June 4, 2008, the IOC Executive Board shortlisted the four strongest bids to become Candidate cities. Those cities were [[Chicago bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics|Chicago]], [[Madrid bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics|Madrid]], [[Rio de Janeiro bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics|Rio de Janeiro]] and [[Tokyo bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics|Tokyo]]; the decisions were made during a meeting in [[Athens]], [[Greece]].<ref name="IOC 2">{{cite web|title=Four cities to compete to host the 2016 Olympic Games|url=http://www.olympic.org/en/content/Media/?articleId=53256|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=June 4, 2008|publisher=International Olympic Committee}}</ref><ref name="BBC 1">{{cite news|title=Four on 2016 Olympics short list|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/olympics/7435215.stm|accessdate =March 2, 2010|date=June 4, 2008|publisher=BBC}}</ref> The remaining Applicant cities—[[Baku bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics|Baku]], [[Doha bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics|Doha]] and [[Prague bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics|Prague]]—were eliminated.<ref>{{cite web|title=2016 Olympic Bid Short List Preview |url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2016_bid_news/1212537937.html |accessdate=March 2, 2010 |date=June 3, 2008 |publisher=GamesBids |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229165907/http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2016_bid_news/1212537937.html |archivedate=December 29, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
The four Candidate cities were selected according to a detailed study of the Applicant Files received by the IOC Working Group on January 14, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=All seven 2016 Applicant Cities return responses|url=http://www.olympic.org/en/content/Media/?articleId=55228|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=January 14, 2008|publisher=International Olympic Committee}}</ref> The four cities submitted the Candidature Files to the IOC on February 11, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=Candidature Procedure 2016 – All four candidate cities submit their files to the IOC|url=http://www.olympic.org/en/content/Media/?articleId=72265|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=February 12, 2009|publisher=International Olympic Committee}}</ref> They were analyzed by the IOC Evaluation Commission, which made site inspections in [[Chicago]] (April 4–7, 2009), [[Tokyo]] (April 16–19, 2009), [[Rio de Janeiro]] (April 27–May 2, 2009) and [[Madrid]] (May 5–8, 2009).<ref>{{cite web|title=2016 Evaluation Commission: Dates of visits to Candidate Cities|url=http://www.olympic.org/en/content/Media/?articleId=53631|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 23, 2008|publisher=International Olympic Committee}}</ref> Under the leadership of [[Nawal El Moutawakel]], the Evaluation Commission released its report on September 2, 2009; one month prior to the election.<ref>{{cite web|title=IOC Releases 2016 Olympic Report|url=http://www.aroundtherings.com/articles/view.aspx?id=33059|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=September 2, 2009|publisher=Around the Rings}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=IOC announces composition of 2016 Evaluation Commission|url=http://www.olympic.org/en/content/Media/?articleId=53567|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=September 18, 2008|publisher=International Olympic Committee}}</ref>
With the presence of the heads of state from all four Candidate cities, the [[121st IOC Session]] took place in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]], on October 2, 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rio to stage 2016 Olympic Games|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/olympic_games/8282518.stm|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 2, 2009|publisher=BBC}}</ref> Chicago began the presentations at [[Bella Center]]; followed by Tokyo, Rio de Janeiro and Madrid; which were attended by several celebrities such as the [[Monarchy of Spain|King of Spain]], [[Oprah Winfrey]] and [[Pelé]].<ref name="IOC A">{{cite web|title=The 2016 Bid Process Explained|url=http://www.olympic.org/en/content/Media/?articleId=73278|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 2, 2009|publisher=International Olympic Committee}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Obama 2016 In Copenhagen - What Bid?|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/bidblog/1216134723.html|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 1, 2009|publisher=GamesBids}}</ref> Before the vote, the IOC Evaluation Commission presented its report to the Session.<ref name="IOC A"/> Chicago fell in the first round, followed by Tokyo, after the eligible IOC members have been asked to vote, in a three-round [[exhaustive ballot]] process.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Olympic Bid Vote – Ballot By Ballot Results|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2016_bid_news/1216134739.html|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 2, 2009|publisher=GamesBids}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Olympic Host City Selection Voting Procedures|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2016_bid_news/1216134724.html|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 1, 2009|publisher=GamesBids}}</ref>
Rio de Janeiro defeated Madrid in the final round by 66 votes over 32, winning the rights to host the [[2016 Summer Olympics]] and [[2016 Summer Paralympics|Paralympics]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Rio de Janeiro Elected As 2016 Host City|url=http://www.olympic.org/en/content/Media/?articleId=73322|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 2, 2009|publisher=International Olympic Committee}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Olympics affirms Brazil's rise, Lula's legacy|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5914MO20091002|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 2, 2009|publisher=Reuters| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100115201153/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5914MO20091002| archivedate= 15 January 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Brazil]] would become the first [[lusophone]] country and Rio de Janeiro the first city in [[South America]] to host the [[Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rio Wins 2016 Olympics in a First for South America|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/03/sports/03olympics.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 2, 2009|publisher=The New York Times | first=Juliet | last=Macur}}</ref> The announcement was made by [[Jacques Rogge]], president of the IOC, in a widely broadcast ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rio de Janeiro to host 2016 Olympics|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/europe/10/02/olympics.2016/index.html|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 2, 2009|publisher=CNN| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100128061559/http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/europe/10/02/olympics.2016/index.html| archivedate= 28 January 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> The lengthy and intensive bidding process, considered to be one of the tightest in history, was marked by several controversies such as espionage, racism and opposition movements.<ref>{{cite web|title=2016 Olympic Bid Timeline – How We Got Here|url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2016_bid_news/1216134720.html|accessdate=March 2, 2010|date=October 1, 2009|publisher=GamesBids}}</ref>
Out of the six cities that failed to be awarded the 2016 Olympics, four of them bid for the [[2020 Summer Olympics]]. Baku, Doha, Madrid and Tokyo were official Applicant Cities, with Madrid and Tokyo advancing to become Candidate Cities and with Tokyo eventually being selected.
==Bidding process== The Olympic bidding process begins with the submission of a city's application to the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) by its [[National Olympic Committee]] (NOC) and ends with the election of the host city by the members of the IOC during an ordinary session. The process is governed by the [[Olympic Charter]], as stated in Chapter 5, Rule 34.<ref name="Charter">{{cite book | url = http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_122.pdf | title = Olympic Charter | publisher = International Olympic Committee |accessdate = 2008-06-04 | date = 2004-09-01 | format = PDF | isbn = 92-9149-001-6 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080609022618/http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_122.pdf| archivedate= 9 June 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
Since 1999, the process has consisted of two phases. During the first phase, which begins immediately after the bid submission deadline, the "applicant cities" are required to answer a questionnaire covering themes of importance to a successful Games organization. This information allows the IOC to analyze the cities' hosting capacities and the strengths and weaknesses of their plans. Following a detailed study of the submitted questionnaires and ensuing reports, the IOC Executive Board selects the cities that are qualified to proceed to the next phase. The second phase is the true candidature stage: the accepted applicant cities (from now on referred to as "candidate cities") are required to submit a second questionnaire in the form of an extended, more detailed, candidature file.<ref name="CityElectionProc">{{cite web | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/organisation/missions/cities_uk.asp | title = Host City Election Procedure | publisher = International Olympic Committee | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080619122311/http://www.olympic.org/uk/organisation/missions/cities_uk.asp| archivedate= 19 June 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> These files are carefully studied by the IOC Evaluation Commission, a group composed of IOC members, representatives of [[List of international sport federations|international sport federations]], NOCs, athletes, the [[International Paralympic Committee]], and international experts in various fields.<ref name="EvalCommis">{{cite web | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/events/117_session/commission_uk.asp | title = Role and composition of the Evaluation Commission | work = 117th IOC Session | publisher = International Olympic Committee | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080613200643/http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/events/117_session/commission_uk.asp| archivedate= 13 June 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> The members of the Evaluation Commission then make four-day inspection visits to each of the candidate cities, where they check the proposed venues and are briefed about details of the themes covered in the candidature file. The Evaluation Commission communicates the results of its inspections in a report sent to the IOC members up to one month before the electing IOC Session.<ref name="CityElectionProc"/>
The IOC Session in which a host city is elected takes place in a country that did not submit an application to stage the Olympics.<ref name="CityElectionProc"/> The election is made by the assembled active IOC members (excluding honorary and honor members), each possessing one vote. Members from countries that have a city taking part in the election cannot vote while the city is in the running. The voting is conducted in a succession of rounds until one bid achieves an [[absolute majority]] of votes; if this does not happen in the first round, the bid with the fewest votes is eliminated and another voting round begins. In the case of a tie for the lowest number of votes, a special runoff vote is carried out, with the winner proceeding to the next round. After each round, the eliminated bid is announced.<ref name="ElectionProc">{{cite web | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/utilities/faq_detail_uk.asp?rdo_cat=24_55_0 | title = FAQ - ELECTION OF AN OLYMPIC GAMES HOST CITY - Host city election | publisher = International Olympic Committee | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080717043751/http://www.olympic.org/uk/utilities/faq_detail_uk.asp?rdo_cat=24_55_0| archivedate= 17 July 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="SingElectionProc">{{cite web | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/events/117_session/election_uk.asp | title = Election procedure | work = 117th IOC Session | publisher = International Olympic Committee | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080601234735/http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/events/117_session/election_uk.asp| archivedate= 1 June 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Following the announcement of the host city, the successful bid delegation signs the "Host City Contract" with the IOC, which delegates the responsibilities of the Games organisation to the city and respective NOC.<ref name="HostCityContract">{{cite web | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/organisation/ocog/index_uk.asp | title = The Organizing Committees of the Olympic Games | work = The Movement | publisher = International Olympic Committee |accessdate = 2008-06-04 }}</ref>
===Evaluation===
====Application phase==== [[File:Cidade Candidata (Rio de Janeiro for the 2016 Olympic Games).JPG|thumbnail|A young girl adds her signature in support of Rio de Janeiro's candidacy to host the 2016 Olympic Games (January 2009)]] The deadline to submit applications for the 2016 Summer Olympic Games was September 13, 2007. The seven cities that submitted bids before that date also met the January 14, 2008 deadline for submission of the first phase questionnaire.<ref name="2016candidproc">{{cite book | url = http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_1318.pdf | title = 2016 Candidature Procedure and Questionnaire | publisher = International Olympic Committee | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | date = 2007-05-16 | format = PDF | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080627111241/http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_1318.pdf | archivedate = 27 June 2008 | deadurl = yes | df = }}</ref> Through analysis of the questionnaires, the IOC gave a [[weighted average|weighted-average]] score to each city based on the scores obtained in each of the questionnaire's eleven themes: political and social support, general [[infrastructure]], sports venues, Olympic Village, environment, accommodation, transport, security, past experience, finance, and legacy. If a bid's score was higher than six (IOC's predefined benchmark score), the city was considered highly capable of hosting the Games; otherwise, its chances were very slim.<ref name="Report1">{{cite book | url = http://www.olympic.org/Documents/Reports/EN/en_report_1317.pdf | title = Report by the IOC candidature acceptance working group to the IOC Executive Board | publisher = International Olympic Committee | date = 2008-03-14 | accessdate = 2012-08-01 | format = PDF | pages = 97 }}</ref> On June 4, 2008, the IOC announced the cities accepted as candidates:<ref name="IOC 1">{{cite press release | title = Four cities to compete to host the 2016 Olympic Games | publisher = International Olympic Committee | date = 2008-06-04 | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/media_centre/press_release_uk.asp?release=2593 | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080607070849/http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/media_centre/press_release_uk.asp?release=2593| archivedate= 7 June 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Four of the five highest-rated applicants progressed to the next phase as official candidate cities.<ref name="2016candidproc"/> As stipulated, the IOC granted them the right to use the [[Olympic rings]] on their candidature emblem, together with a label identifying each as a Candidate City. The International Olympic Committee went against precedent when it selected Rio de Janeiro over Doha—a city which scored higher yet was eliminated from the field. Doha's weaknesses of a small population, lack of facilities, and Games dates outside of the IOC's desired window may have been too large an obstacle for the IOC to accept.<ref>{{cite news | title = IOC Bends Rules When Selecting 2016 Olympic Bid Shortlist | work = 2016 Summer Olympic Games | publisher = GamesBids.com | date = 2008-06-04 | url = http://www.gamesbids.com/cgi-bin/news/viewnews.cgi?category=1&id=1212598324 | accessdate = 2008-06-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080607070718/http://www.gamesbids.com/cgi-bin/news/viewnews.cgi?category=1&id=1212598324| archivedate= 7 June 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Typically, the IOC selects all the top scoring bids which reach the established minimum benchmark.
The Working Group divided the Evaluation Report on eleven detailed themes and weightings: Government support, legal issues and public opinion (2);<ref name="IOC WG 3">{{Cite book | title = 2016 Working Group Report | url = http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_1317.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = July 15, 2009 | date = March 14, 2008 | publisher = (IOC) | location = [[Lausanne]], [[Switzerland]] | pages = 16–25 | chapter = Government support, legal issues and public opinion | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090903152653/http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_1317.pdf | archivedate = September 3, 2009 | df = }}</ref> General infrastructure (5);<ref name="IOC WG 4">{{Cite book | title = 2016 Working Group Report | url = http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_1317.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = July 15, 2009 | date = March 14, 2008 | publisher = (IOC) | location = [[Lausanne]], [[Switzerland]] | pages = 26–35 | chapter = General infrastructure | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090903152653/http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_1317.pdf | archivedate = September 3, 2009 | df = }}</ref> Sports venues (4);<ref name="IOC WG 5">{{Cite book | title = 2016 Working Group Report | url = http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_1317.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = July 15, 2009 | date = March 14, 2008 | publisher = (IOC) | location = [[Lausanne]], [[Switzerland]] | pages = 38–49 | chapter = Sports venues | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090903152653/http://multimedia.olympic.org/pdf/en_report_1317.pdf | ====Candidature phase==== [[Nawal El Moutawakel]] of Morocco headed the Evaluation Commission. She also chaired the evaluation commission for the [[2012 Summer Olympics bids]]. Other members include Olympic Games Executive Director Gilbert Felli, IOC Member [[Ching-Kuo Wu]] from [[Chinese Taipei]], IOC Member [[Craig Reedie]] from Great Britain, IOC Member [[Guy Drut]] from France, IOC Member [[Mounir Sabet]] from Egypt, IOC Member and Athletes' Commission Representative [[Alexander Popov (swimmer)|Alexander Popov]] from Russia, IOC Member and ASOIF Representative Els van Breda Vriesman from The Netherlands and IPC Representative Gregory Hartung from Australia.
The Commission made on-site inspections in the second quarter of 2009. visiting Chicago April 2 to 8, Tokyo April 14 to 20, Rio de Janeiro April 27 to May 3, and Madrid May 4 to 9. In a change from previous years, the commission's visits were extended from four days to seven.<ref>[http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2016_bid_news/1216133836.html IOC Announces Inspection Dates Of 2016 Bid Cities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081023220037/http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2016_bid_news/1216133836.html |date=2008-10-23 }}</ref> They issued a comprehensive technical appraisal for IOC members one month before the elections in October 2009.<ref>[http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/1216133733.html IOC Announces 2016 Summer Games Evaluation Commission] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226104454/http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/1216133733.html |date=February 26, 2009 }}</ref>
===Election=== At the [[121st International Olympic Committee Session|121st IOC Session]] in Copenhagen, Denmark on October 2, 2009, final voting took place. The three ballots were held within a 15 minutes period, and although the first two ballots results were announced immediately, the third ballot result was announced only about one hour later.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lyon|first1=Sam|title=Olympic decision as it happened|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/olympic_games/8283061.stm|website=BBC.co.uk|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=25 April 2016}}</ref> The final result and winner was announced as Rio de Janeiro at 18:49, Copenhagen time (16:49 [[UTC]]). until the Olympics.<ref name="BOC 1">{{cite web|url=http://www.cob.org.br/noticias/noticias_interna.asp?id=4584|title=Rio is the Brazilian applicant city for the 2016 Summer Olympics|author=Brazilian
